slides.title: How to Study Effectively (Without Studying More Hours)
slides.subtitle: Practical techniques to learn more in less time
slides.speaker: Intro: quick promise — technique beats time.

slides.title: The Problem
bullets: Most people “study,” but don’t learn.
Re-reading notes feels productive, but doesn’t stick
Highlighting makes you familiar, not fluent
Real learning happens when your brain has to retrieve and apply
slides.speaker: If studying feels easy, it’s probably not working.

slides.title: The 3 Rules of Effective Study
bullets: Active recall: force your brain to pull information out
Spaced repetition: revisit over time, not in one big block
Deliberate practice: target what you get wrong, not what you already know
slides.speaker: These three are the difference between ‘I saw it’ and ‘I can do it.’

slides.title: Active Recall (What to Do)
bullets: Replace passive methods with these:
Blurting: close notes → write everything you remember → check gaps
Practice questions: exam-style problems, not summaries
Teach-back: explain the concept like you’re tutoring someone
slides.example: Quick example: Instead of “read the chapter,” do: “Answer 10 questions, then mark and fix errors.”
slides.speaker: Demonstrate one quick blurting example live.

slides.title: Spacing + Interleaving (How to Schedule)
bullets: Spacing: shorter sessions over multiple days beats cramming
Day 0: learn
Day 1: recall
Day 3: recall again
Day 7: mixed practice
Interleaving: mix topics, don’t do one topic for 3 hours straight
It feels harder → it works better
Helps you choose the right method under pressure (like in exams)
slides.speaker: Scheduling that forces retrieval beats marathon re-reading.

slides.title: The Feedback Loop (How to Improve Fast)
bullets: After every session, ask: What did I get wrong? Why?
What pattern keeps repeating?
What will I do next session to fix it?
Rule: Your mistakes are your study plan.
Spend 70% of time on weak areas, 30% on review.
slides.speaker: Focus your next session on the recurring mistakes.

slides.title: A Simple 45-Min Study Template (Practical)
bullets: 0–5 min: set goal (specific outcome)
5–25 min: active recall / questions
25–35 min: mark + error log
35–45 min: re-attempt wrong questions + schedule next review
slides.speaker: No fancy motivation needed—just a system.

slides.title: Closing
bullets: Effective studying isn’t about time. It’s about technique.
If you do only one change: swap re-reading for retrieval (practice questions + recall), then space it out.
slides.speaker: 20 seconds: leave them with one concrete swap.
